div.p:
My dear Sir, I fear you will be surprised
by the celerity of our thanks for your letter,
this moment received, and that you will
apprehend a tax upon your valuable time
from such a frequent correspondance -
But you need not - for I assure you I shall
not encroach upon your leisure - I know
its importance - your praise, and your cri-
ticism criticism , and your suggestions, are such as we
canseldom meet with; and could you
know the delight with which your letters
are heard by our family circle you would
not think you have obliged ungrateful
people

I will not mix any literature with
the business of this my letter - I wrote to you a
few days ago, directing my letter to my
son Henry in London desiring that he would
present or forward it by post to you im=
=mediately immediately ; but I fear, from your last
just received, that mine will not reach
you; therefore I write again to repeat t
he purport of mine.

My son Henry is going to Madei
ra
Madeira
, where an English physician, as we are
told, will have practice; he has good recom-
=mendations recommendations , and will spend two or three
years in that Island, and hopes to return
with increased experience, and with the repu-
tation
reputation
of having been abroad, to settle in >Dub
=lin
Dublin
. We hear that Lord Lansdowne is going
to Madeira, - if my son's services during
the voyage can be made acceptable to his
Lordship it will be an advantageous -
- I rely on your friendly recommendation
div.closer:
With true esteem & regard I am
My dear Sir
Yours sincerely
Richr Lovell Edgeworth

postscript.p: perhaps we may meet in London next winter

Your writing is to us as legible as print
- whether you write fast or with care Therefore
do not trouble yourself to write about it.
